bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, December 10, 1939

div1.p: Hench offers advice on the structure of the Washington and Jefferson College Founders' Day program and makes recommendations for possible speakers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, December 10, 1939
div1.p:
I have always known that you and I were on rapport. I was thinking of
you and of Founder's Day the other night, and came down to the Clinic in the morning,
prepared to write you a letter when I received yours.

Consider this a list of preliminary suggestions. I have discussed your
proposed program with Dr. Louis B. Wilson, the Director Emeritus of the Mayo Foundation,
and with Dr. Tom Magath, the head of our department of tropical and allied diseases.
Both of these men are familiar with the ability of nationally known speakers. I believe
you said that you wanted two or three speakers, and it seemed to us that these speeches
should be arranged somewhat as follows:
Speech No. 1: An introductory, short talk, telling the laymen the human inter-
est story of what Lazear and his colleagues actually did, omitting entirely or only
briefly touching on the implications of their work.
Speech No. 2: A nationally known medical man who would bring to your
audience the value of the work of Lazear and his colleagues, and show its influence on
medical progress, not only in the United States but also in the world.
Speech No. 3: A nationally known speaker, medical or otherwise, from Latin
America, a sort of “hands across the sea” speaker, which you had in mind when you thought
of Lord Dawson. This man should again extole the work of Lazear and speak of how great
his contribution was to the Latin American countries in wiping out yellow fever. He
should also mention the importance of this work to the northern countries, particularly
now that tripical diseases are so readily transferrable to the North by airplane
communication.
Now as to the suggestions:

Our first suggestion was Dr. W. A. Sawyer, Director of the Rockefeller Founda-
tion, to give the second speech mentioned above. You might want some important Latin
American speaker such as Professor Houssay, Professior of Physiology at Buenos Aires,
or better yet, Sumner Wells, Undersecretary of State.

list.item:
1. Dr. W. A. Sawyer is about sixty years of age, I believe. He is Director
of the Rockefeller Foundation, is a world authority on yellow fever, has won many medals,
and I am informed that he is a brilliant speaker and that he knew all of the men personally
working with Reed and Lazear. I believe he won the Walter Reed medal from the American
Society of Tropical Medicine, and Magath tells me that he is the logical successor to
the work of Reed and Lazear. Magath says that he is the supreme authority on yellow
fever besides being an excellent speaker and a man who has done many important research
problems himself on the disease.

2. As the layman speaker to give speech No. 3 (in lieu of a South American
speaker), we would suggest Sumner Wells, Undersecretary of State. I am told by those
who have heard him that he is an excellent speaker and while he might or might not know

directly of the work of Lazear and Carroll, he could inform himself of it, and be an
excellent man to show the social implications of the importance of their work to
governments. As you know, Wells is a leading authority on Latin American traditions.
He would be a good name for you on the program, and incidentally, just recently gave a
talk on the “policy and program of the United States government in its international
cultural relationships.”

3. Perhaps you might get Secretary Hull. Although Hull must be very busy,
with the war going on, I understand that he is a willing speaker if he can improve inter-
national relations and of course he would have the opportunity, not only to mention the
outstanding work of Dr. Carlos Finlay of Cuba, (whose idea set Reed and his committee
on the right track) but would also have a chance to give a “hands across the sea” talk
using international medical cooperation as his theme.

4. As an alternate, either to Wells or Hull, Wells has an excellent assistant
who, next to him, is the leading authority in the State Department on Latin American
affairs. He is an excellent speaker. I don't have his name at the moment, but we could
get it.

5. As an alternate for Sawyer, both Wilson and Magath recommended most highly,
Dr. Herbert C. Clark, head of the Gorgas Institute in Panama. He, too, knew the men
concerned with the Yellow Fever Commission, and worked with Gorgas. He is an excellent
speaker, spends half of his time in Panama at the Gorgas Institute and the other hald
as Professor of Pathology at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

div1.p:
It seemed to us that the program with Dr. Sawyer as the medical representative
and Sumner Wells as the layman diplomatic representative would be ideal, with Herbert
Clark as an alternate for Sawyer.

Other men whose names were suggested: (Their merits and demerits are as
follows, but these men were considered of secondary importance).

list.item:
1. Surgeon General Hugh S. Cummings, Director of Pan-American Sanitary Bureau,
Washington. Wilson called him a “magnificent speaker”. Magath called him a “good talker”.
However, he is a retired Surgeon General, is about sixty five, and is perhaps too old
to put on a program that you want to have all set six months in advance.

2. Dr. John A. Ferrell, Associate Director of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Wilson called him a “good speaker”. Magath called him a clear speaker but one with “a
rather monotonous, soft voice”.

3. Dr. Henry a Moe of Cuggenheim Memorial Foundation, New York City, a good
talker who could talk on the social importance of yellow fever throughout the world.

div1.p:
Others who were suggested but turned down strongly for various reasons were:
1. Surgeon General Parran of the United States Department of Public Health.
He is well known to the laymen and is a good talker but his two pet hobbies are venereal

diseases and the care of the medical indigent, and it might be very hard for him
to speak on anything else than this, unless he were definitely assigned a topic to
conform with your program.
2. Surgeon General Magic of the Army, but he was considered a poor speaker.
he knows nothing of yellow fever and would have to look up everything.
3. Surgeon General McIntyre, Roosevelt's physician. His only merit would
be that he is Roosevelt's physician and his name is known to the laymen, but he is a
nose and throat man and doesn't know a darned thing about yellow fever.
4. Morris Fishbein, Editor of the Journal of the A.M.A. At another time,
I would have recommended him heartily. He is a nationally known speaker, one of the
most rapid speakers I have ever heard, and at times, one of the most excellent. He
sprinkles his speeches with amusing stories, but you have to be a little careful be-
cause some of those stories are slightly off color--all right for medical audiences, but
perhaps not for laymen. At the moment, however, he is very much in the doghouse among
American Medical men because of his uncompromising attitude regarding the problem of
social medicine.
5. Rock Sleyster, President of the American Medical Association. But he is
not an inspiring speaker and would probably want to give his speech No. 5, which is
merely a rehash of his speech No. 1 on socialized medicine.

I also thought of some Nobel Prize winner, whose name would be known. Most
of them are not very good speakers. Minot of Boston (Nobel Prize for liver for perni-
cious anemia) is only a fair speaker--mutters and mumbles.

Murphy, his co-Nobel laureate, is a very poor speaker. Whipple, who was the
third man to win the Nobel Prize for this work, is a much better speaker, but is less
known than the others.

Banting, Nobel Prize for insulin, is in the army, and you don't want to count
on him because he might be in Europe at that time. Best, co-discoverer of insulin,
did not win the Nobel Prize, but is very well known, is a young man thirty five years
old, and a good speaker, but not in the class with the others.

Domagk, the current Nobel Prize winner is in Germany, and of course, you could
not get anybody from Europe. I doubt very much if Lord Dawson or anyone else would come
and risk the trans-Atlantic crossing.

Incidentally, one of the doctors concerned with the experiments, in a minor
role, is still living--Dr. Cook. I can send you his address. He must be fairly old
by now. You might invite him and perhaps you would want him to speak informally.
Indeed, you might want him to give the human interest story, but as a member of the
group, he might be too modest to do this.

At this point, may I say that I don't want you to feel in the slightest
committed to me as the one to give the human interest story. If you want two speakers,
it is quite probable that Dr. Sawyer could give as much of the story as you want, and I
would be delighted either to give him the material I have in toto, or at some very
informal meeting to supplement his remarks by some lantern slides which I have collected,

December 10, 1939
showing the various characters concerned, the site of their army research camp, etc.
I am completely in earnest about this, and I don't think you ought to make committments
as far as my talk is concerned.

Now as to the men from here. We have no one sufficiently informed about
yellow fever, to be in a class with the men I have mentioned.
Dr. Balfour is a fairly good speaker, is Director of the Mayo Foundation.

Dr. Wilson himself has been an excellent speaker, but has now retired, and
is well over seventy. He is rather frail, and if you put him on the program, he might
be dead by the time the day arrives.

These, confidentially, are not only my opinions, but those of Magath, and are
of course, confidential.

Finally, as to the two other suggestions, Dr. Lahey of Boston is merely a
good surgeon. His reputation among medical men is good, but his reputation among
laymen is of the slightest, and he couldn't hold a candle to some I have mentioned.
Dr. Abel was dismissed by Dr. Wilson as “just another Southern doctor.”

In conclusion, our first suggestions are Dr. Sawyer and Sumner Wells.
You mustn't feel obligated in the slightest toward these suggestions, and I shall be
delighted to make any further inquiries that you may wish me to make, and of course
consider it confidential.

closer.seg:
P.S. I shall most certainly increase my check to $150.00 Can I send it to
you dated January 17 Heavens to Betsy, if I can add $50.00 and get my name engraved in
bronze at W. and J. it is most assuredly worth it! I will do it on one condition,
however, that after it, you will put “Lafayette, '16”!
